title: Why does the world in the DC Universe look so much like our own, considering their technology is so extremely advanced? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is it? Well of course that the world looks pretty much like ours except with the addition of super-stuff is a convention of the genre along with the costumes, secret identities, ineffectiveness of guns and ability of everyone to make complete recovery from dozens of brain traumas. It appeals to the audience to have the stories set in a generally familiar world. And it’s important that supervillains not be something that regular cops and soldiers can handle otherwise there’s no reason for superheroes. So the “advanced technology” is kept from general distribution by heroes and villains who want to preserve their edge, or is simply impossible to mass produce. Maybe it requires imaginary elements that are in too short a supply to make it economical, or alien components that can’t be locally produced, or the help of actual superpowers to make.

Status quo and relatability. There a fiction trope called “Reed Richards Is Useless”-referring to the point that despite having people on the planet that can travel across space and time, not to mention rebuild reality with the click of a button, the worlds in comics are still like ours. It’s to make the comic characters and settings more relatable to the reader. The worlds are till mostly rooted in reality, while certain cities in DC are entirely fictional and can be messed around with a bit. If these people with these powers and technology actually applied their resources to better the world, these comic Earths could be utopias. All diseases cured, no world hunger-it would be a world of the future; a sci-fi utopia. By keeping the setting more real, the conflicts that fuel the stories can happen. Time and again “what if” stories have explored settings where the powered populace actually saved the world. These are usually limited series and one-shots, as they’re just made to show what could happen.
